The robot player tries to trap the other player with his robots, by splitting each roll among however many robots he wishes. Not only are the robots inherently ¼ the speed of the spaceman, but they also are unable to move backward, toward the ship. As a result, the robot player must be attentive in his move choices. Fortunately for him, most of the board has four or fewer chokepoints to cover at any given vertical slice; unfortunately, players are neither allowed to waste pips from their die roll, nor retread a space on the same turn.

11858.name: Adultery
11858.description: From the rules: The object of the game is spend a good time with 2 different players of the opposite sex. NOTE: Drinks & Mixes should be close at hand. Players spin and move their game piece around the board getting tokens worth two, three and five minutes. When all players have three time tokens, players are selected at random to retire to another part of the house. Game ends when each player had the chance to spend time in private with two different players.

11859.name: Air Trix
11859.description: Race against the clock to score points in this fascinating jet stream action game. Maneuver the ball on a cushion of air through the rungs of the ladder, onto to barrel on the seal's nose, through the weather vane into the bucket and finally into the helicopter cockpit to pick up the mail. You score points for each stunt. The player with the highest score wins.

11860.name: Balaroo
11860.description: The game board is a motorized, rotating platform with twelve colored spaces and a swing arm with a "wrecker ball" at the end. Players bet on how long their piece will remain standing with points awarded for win, place or show, but in the end, the last player standing is the winner.

11861.name: Bang Box
11861.description: Inflate a number of balloons equal to one less than the total number of players and place them under the Bang Box. Each player on their turn spins the spinner and must drive that number of nails into any holes of their choice without busting a balloon. When a player bursts a balloon that player is out of the game. The remaining players continue until there is only one player left, the winner!

11862.name: Gay Monopoly
11862.description:
"Gay Monopoly - A celebration of gay life."

Tongue in cheek version of the classic Monopoly. Player tokens are altered - now you can choose from a jeep, teddy bear, blow drier, leather cap, handcuffs or a stiletto heel. Properties have been changed to a 'gay' theme as well - e.g. Fire Island and Castro Street. Instead of buying houses and hotels, you can buy bars and bathhouses. The money denominations include $3.00 bills.

One departure from the original Monopoly is the inclusion of Family Pride cards. When landing on the appropriate space, the description of a famous gay man is read aloud, and the player who can correctly identify the person can move ahead to any space on the board. Also different is the addition of Camp Cards. When these are drawn, you must perform the indicated action (ie. 'say: 'faaabulous!' six different ways and receive $3). Finally, there are "hanky code" cards, where the player must identify what each color of the code meant, and what it meant when worn in each (left and right) rear pants pocket.

Rumor has it that there were only a very limited number of copies of this game, as it was produced by The Parker Sisters, a division of Fire Island games, and were sued for copyright infringement by Parker Brothers (the company is no longer in business).

11863.name: Rock Paper Scissors
11863.description: The object of the game is to complete all of the squares on the game board using the Rock Paper Scissors selectors.

11864.name: Great Alaskan Clean-Up
11864.description:
From the introduction:

"Just suppose that there is an Oil Company, and it's called EX-CON. And suppose that it has tankers cruising all around the world, delivering oil. And suppose that one of these tankers is sailing around off the coast of Alaska. And just suppose the captain can't hold his liquor and has headed back to his cabin to sleep it off. And just suppose that the guy in charge of swabbing the deck is now piloting the ship and he accidentally hits a reef with the ship and spills oil all over the coast of Alaska. This situation is, of course, theoretical. But if this did happen, then you'd have... THE GREAT ALASKAN CLEAN-UP"

11865.description:
A traditional two-players Japanese card game played with the beautiful Hanafuda (literally 'Flower card') deck.

Setup: the cards are all shuffled, and one card is randomly revealed: the player whom the birthday month is closer to the revealed card month is the first player and thus the dealer. The cards are shuffled again and handed out, two by two, to both players, as for the face-up talon in the middle of the table.

Turn: Then each player proceeds as so: firstly, he discards a card face up on the table from his hand. If that card matches another card on the table (matching months), the player then wins both cards which he puts in his face-up collection, in front of him. The collection is always displayed in 4 columns, as so: Flowers, Ribbons, Animals and Specials. If it doesn't match anything, the discarded card stays on the table. Secondly, whether it matched or not, the player then draws the first card from the face down deck, and proceeds the same way: if it doesn't match any card, the drawn card stays on the table, but if it does match a card, the player wins both cards which he adds to his collection. Then the other player takes his turn.

Turn's End: At the end of a player's turn, if he has any Yaku, he can stop the current month (inning) by stating his Yakus, then the points are scored and the next month begins. However, if he wishes to continue in order to increase his score for this month, he says "Koi-Koi" and the other player takes his turn. If later on during the game, the player who said Koi-Koi wins another Yaku OR increases his previous Yakus, he can then again stop the game or say Koi-Koi, as many times as he wants. But if a player gets a Yaku in a game where his opponent already said Koi-Koi, then he gets the right either to say Koi-Koi too, or to stop the game and receive his points, thus leading his opponent to get no points at all this month.

End: Since each player has 8 cards in his hand, a month (inning) can at worse last 16 turns. In case of a game where one (or both) player(s) said Koi-Koi and no more Yakus have been added or increased before the month ends, then only the last player who said Koi-Koi scores his points as usual. The winner of a month becomes the dealer for the next month, or stays the same if there was not any winner.

Each Yaku can add itself to the others. Here are the Yakus:

Basic Yakus

10 Flowers / Kasu : 1 point (Each additional Flower adds 1 point)
5 Ribbons / Tanzaku : 1 point (Each additional Ribbon adds 1 point)
3 Purple Ribbons (blue) / Aotan : 5 points
3 Ribbons with Poems (red) / Akatan : 5 points
5 Animals / Tane : 1 Point (Each additional Animal adds 1 point)
Doe + Boar + Butterflies / Ino Shika Chô : 5 Points
3 Specials without the Rain Man / Sankô : 5 Points
4 Specials with the Rain Man / Ameshikô : 6 points
4 Special without the Rain Man / Shikô : 8 Points
5 Specials : Gokô : 10 points

Special Yakus

The Moon + The Sake Cup / Tsukizake : 5 points (Bonus Yaku, only in addition to at least another normal Yaku)
The Cherry Curtain + The Sake Cup / Hanamizake : 5 points (Bonus Yaku, only in addition to at least another normal Yaku)
The Iris Flower is a "Joker" card: it can either be counted as an Animal, or as Flower to form a Kasu (but not both).
The 4 Cards of the current Month / TsukiFuda : 5 points
No Yakus / OyaKen : 1 point

The game ends when one player reaches 50 points. In some variants, at the end of a month, the points scored by a player are subtracted from his opponent's score. In some variants, the player with the most points at the end of the year (December) wins the game.
11865.name: Koi-Koi
boardgamepodcastepisode: Podcast EP06 – Board Game Arena
Printin’ and Playin’ Episode 22 – Hanafuda / Koi Koi / Go Stop

11866.name: Triple Flips 1: Horses
11866.description:
Triple Flips 1 includes Steeplechase Championships, Ride-em Cowboy, and Ride the High Country.


Steeplechase Championships, for 2-4 players, uses a linear path of obstacles, each labeled with the rolls (on two dice) required to pass it. For instance, to start, you need to roll 2-5; then to clear the water jump, 6-9; then for the brick wall, 10-12. To clear the logs at the end, you need to roll doubles.



Ride-em Cowboy (a rodeo game for 1-4 players) is a game in which it is appropriately difficult to score well. Appropriately for simulating a rodeo, players often won't stay on the bronco long enough to score, but, on the other hand, occasionally someone will ride the whole way out.



Ride the High Country is just a basic roll-and-move game for 2-4 players.

11867.name: Triple Flips 2: Monsters
11867.description:
Triple Flips 2 includes Curse of the Pyramid, Vampire Attack, and Escape the Evil Castle.


Curse of the Pyramid is a race game for 1 player. You mark half the dice numbers as belonging to the mummy, then roll the die. If the mummy's numbers get rolled, he moves toward the goal; if not, then you move the actual number rolled. Of course, your path is substantially longer than his. You also are required to change the mummy's numbers each turn.



Vampire Attack lets 2-4 players attempt to bite each other. On your turn, roll the die, then move orthogonally with up to one 90° turn per move, in an attempt to sidle up to another player. Once you get orthogonally adjacent to an opponent, roll again. A 1 (appropriately, the big, red pip) means you've bitten them and they're out of the game.



Escape the Evil Castle is a spiteful race game for 2-4 players. Players traverse a linear path toward the goal, advancing the roll of a die each turn. However, your roll also moves Dracula, whom you can move in either direction. If you move Dracula onto an opponent, she must move her pawn back to the 0%, 25%, 50%, or 75% mark.

11868.description:
Goal is to get rid of your own cards as fast as possible. First the table cards are laid out - leaving space in between for other cards. The other cards are dealt out. The active player can play up to three cards placing them along one of the table cards with a suitable motive. If a player can't place any cards he has to pass. Table cards with four played cards are removed from the game and the surrounding cards are dealt to the one who last placed a card. Winner is the player with the least cards who didn't have to pass.

Es gilt, seine Handkarten möglichst gut abzuspielen.
Am Anfang werden die Tischkarten im Zentrum offen ausgelegt. Dabei sollte zwischen den Karten so viel Platz bleiben, daß man an jede Kante eine Karte legen kann.
Die Spielkarten werden gründlich gemischt und dann an die
11868.name: Playmobil: Alarm! Alarm!

11869.description: Goal is to collect the most toys (cards) of one category. First 16 cards are laid out face down into a 4x4 grid. The remaining cards become the draw pile. The players choose a figure and place it next to one of the laid out cards. The active player throws the die and moves his figure along the side of the field - in the direction he chooses. The player may than turn around as many cards in a row as allowed by the die - the cards remain face up till the end of the game. He may take one card replacing it with a card from the draw pile - face down. The game ends as soon as the draw pile is exhausted.
11869.name: Alles in Ordnung

11870.description: Each player draws two tiles. The remaining tiles are placed face down on the table. Each player also receives 5 stripes face up depicting a dirty figure with a "clean side" face down. Every a turn a player selects a tile. If he got a tile with the picture of a flannel he has to turn one stripe of his figure from the dirty side to the clean side. Otherwise he looks whether he now has a trio of motives or background colors. If so, he keeps the trio and draws another two tiles. As soon as one figure of any player is perfectly clean the game ends and the one with the most trios wins.
11870.name: Badetag

11872.name: Don't Miss the Boat
11872.description:
CONTENTS
yellow island, yellow cone
8 balls on strings
8 boats
4x 3playing pieces, dice

OBJECT OF THE GAME
to be the first player to get all three playing pieces onto the island.

HOW TO PLAY
Each player takes 3 playing pieces of one color and places them in any 3 separate boats. At the start not more than 2 men per boat.
During the game not more than 3 men per boat are allowed.
Each player in turn, throws the dice and moves any one of his men from boat to boat. A player must also select a ball from the central cone to pull in one of the boats.
If the boat pulled ashore contains the player's own play piece then he may place it on the island. If the place on the island is already occupied by an opponent's piece then the play pieces are exchanged.

11873.name: AMC Reel Clues
11873.description:
From the box: If you like movies, you'll love AMC Reel Clues. Teams race a timer to provide answers to clever clues about popular movies and our favorite stars. The first team t collect the right combinations of stars, directors, screenplays and locations win the game!

Family and friends will have fun identifying mystery stars, drawing pictures and impersonating celebrities. Five different types of clues keep things lively, so every player can laugh, learn and live the Hollywood business.

11874.name: Dabol
11874.description:
The game from Johann Cruyff. Dabol recreates a football game tactically. There is a Die for each player, you can create teams selecting dices from 1 to 16. Each Die has a variable values. The values represent pass, movement, kick and defense. The ball is placed in the field through the different areas of play.

The field is divided in 8 parts each representing the playing areas in a soccer field.

The rules are simple but at the same time with a lot of tactical options. It is a rare game published at the end of 20th century.

11875.name: Civil War 2061
11875.description: A Risk-type variant, Civil War 2061 explores a possible future of the United States of America, one where the states have broken into different factions, facing off against one another for total control of the USA. The New South has risen again, and must deal with not only the US governmental troops, but militia from other states. Two to six players decide the leadership of the new United States!

11876.name: Sentence Says
11876.description:
The components of Sentence Says are: 4 sets of oversized cards: vowel cards, consonant cards, action cards and steal cards, 4 oversized sand timers: 15, 30, 45, and 60 seconds and 1 oversized custom die.

The object of Sentence Says is to create a sentence out of letter cards that you are dealt, using each letter as the first letter of a word of your choice. For example, the letter "C" could become "Cat", "Could" or any word that you choose beginning with the letter "C".

So, if you were dealt a hand consisting of the letters: M,F,G,A,B,P, you could create the sentence: "Freddy's Billy Goat Ate Pancakes Monday"...or "Get Powder Because My Foot Aches!". You can arrange the cards in any order to create your sentence. But you are under a time limit and the time depends on how many cards you are dealt (anywhere from 5-7 depending on the roll of the die). There is also an action card that you must draw before turning over your cards. The action cards give you an instruction for completing your sentence, such as "Your sentence must be in the form of a question" or "Do not use a proper name".

Points are at the bottom of every card. You accumulate points by creating an acceptable sentence within the time limit. You can also wager points by stealing when an opponent misses a sentence.

The fun of the game is coming up with well thought-out sentences and hearing the silly sentences that people try to get away with (and of course, winning). It's perfect to play a one on one session or in a large group at a party.

Sentence Says is brand new game and is available at select specialty retail outlets or online at www.sentencesays.com

11877.name: Families in Nature
11877.description:
Discover the most fascinating inhabitants on Earth! A card game unlike any other, which combines comical illustrations and multiple choice questions. Players will discover and understand the relationship between creatures and their natural habitats.

Game Principles and Objectives : Collect the animal and plant species (birds, flowers...) living in identical natural habitats (tropical forests, deserts...). To get a card, players must guess which player has the desired card and also answer the question correctly. Answers are fully explained and illustrated.

11878.name: Life in Colonial Williamsburg
11878.description: Step back in time! This exciting game is a virtual visit to Williamsburg. First, choose one of eight characters: merchants, milliner, tavern keeper, slave... Then, with the roll of a die, explore the colonial capital. Stop at points of interest, experience everyday and historic events and collect Colonial LifeTokens along the way. The first to collect all seven wins! Category cards--Meet the People, Colonial Events and Pages in History--add spice to the game with questions and commands. Be careful--you might wind up in the stocks, or even on trial at the Capital. Three levels of play; great fun for Ages 8 and up.

11879.name: The American Girls Collection Card Game
11879.description: Have fun while learning more about the American Girls with this rummy-style card game. The deck of 64 cards features full-color illustrations from the stories of all eight American Girls.

11880.name: Pro Football
11880.description: Simple American Football game using spinners to determine the types of plays and reactions. Very random game-play with little strategy. Not to be confused with 3M's 1966 game of the same title or the 1969 Chapman Pro Football.

11881.name: The Mad Microbe
11881.description:
A simple game about dental hygiene.

Two tracks are side-by-side on the board, one for the "dentist" player, and one for the "germ" player. Players try to get to the finish first by rolling a die, and trying to avoid spots on the track that will cause them to lose turns or have to move backwards.

11882.description:
From the box: Strike for goal in this simple game of tactics which is easy to learn and fun to play.

An abstract strategy game with a soccer theme. Strategically move your pieces to score a goal off your opponent.
11882.name: 3-A-Side

11883.name: Trivial Pursuit: Volume 6
11883.description: All-new edition. 4,800 new general knowledge questions in 6 categories. Answer questions correctly to collect all the wedges in your pie. Then race to the center of the game board to win. The same play and categories as past Trivial Pursuit games.

11884.name: New York Scene
11884.description:
From the back:

"The excitement of Broadway, a shopping spree along Fifth Avenue, elegant dining among the skyscrapers of Manhattan, and a tour of the city's famous landmarks - all these are a part of the New York Scene.

Have you ever wanted to own the Mets, Tiffany's, the Plaza Hotel or the Daily News? Now is your chance by playing the New York Scene!

- you will buy and sell your favorite local properties;

- become either a union leader, a lawyer, a politician, or a network executive;

- bargain with the other players to receive a "Connection Card" which will permit you to develop your properties and thereby collect increased rent.

The object of the New York Scene is to accumulate wealth and enjoy a unique witty and up-to-date view of the exciting way of life in New York. During the Game you will draw New York Scene Cards which will reward or penalize - for example:

-- The Aussie Strikes Again - You may Buy Any or All of the Newspapers for Twice Their Stated Purchase Price

-- You're Riding the Subway, the Hand in Your Pocket Belongs to Someone Else - Lose Two Turns Due to Shock"

11885.name: Jewels in the Sand
11885.description: An inductive game where one player plays the Sultan who creates a rule for separating Jewel objects from Sand objects. The other players (the Thieves) work together to come up with guesses to what the rule is, to which the Sultan responds counter examples to disapprove. Once a rule has been guessed the Sultan scores and a new round begins with a new Sultan.

11886.description:
Block wargame. From Columbia Games:

The campaigns for Texas Independence were much more than just the Alamo. Texas Glory includes the preliminary 1835 clashes when the Texans under Austin expelled the Mexican garrison from San Antonio de Bejar. It then covers Santa Anna's 1836 surprise late winter campaign that began with his recapture of the Alamo, but ended with Texan victory at the Battle of San Jacinto on April 21,1836.

This fast-playing game reflects the balanced struggle between the Mexicans and the Texans. Sam Houston must delay superior Mexican forces until he can gather enough troops to risk a battle. The Mexicans must sweep across Texas with utmost speed because time and supply are their enemies. The significant role of "American Volunteers" in the eventual outcome becomes clear.

Texas Glory FAQ
11886.name: Texas Glory: 1835-36
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 44: Grant and Tom Dalgliesh on Columbia Games and the new, Kickstarted edition of Napoleon

11887.name: Monopoly: Corvette
11887.description:
From the back of the box:
"Shift into high gear with 50 years of your favorite corvette models. Experience the thrill of owning the most collectible Corvette cars ever produced.

"The Corvette debuted in 1953 at the General Motors Motorama at New York's posh Waldorf Astoria and has since become the uncontested master of the American-made sports car. The MONOPOLY Brand proudly introduces a game designed exclusively for the dedicated Corvette collector. Featuring 50 years of celebrated vintage shark coupes, classic Sting Ray convertibles and the limited edition 50th Anniversary, this version of the world's most famous board game puts you right in the driver's seat.

"Fuel your Corvette passion -- play this high performance edition of the MONOPOLY game and leave the competition in the dust."

11888.name: Bataille de la Marne 1914
11888.description:
Battle of the Marne River - 1914

French, British and German units, most of the which are divisions and artillery groups. Each country uses its own Combat Result table
Scale is about 2.5 miles per hex.

11889.description: End of the Iron Dream covers the last full year of World War II in Europe, starting from the D-Day invasion. Published in The Wargamer Magazine #42.
11889.name: End of the Iron Dream

11890.name: Triple Four
11890.description:
From the publisher:
It's FUN- times 3 -when you play this exciting family card game! Match three of your playing cards to a "Triplet" card. And don't forget...Jokers are WILD! Be the first to collect four groups of matching cards and you win the game! With a little strategy and the luck of the draw, you could score a TRIPLE FOUR! It's three times the fun for the whole family.

CONTENTS:
2 DECKS PLAYING CARDS
1 DECK "TRIPLET" CARDS
4 CUSTOM CARD TRAYS
GAME INSTRUCTIONS

11891.name: How Tall am I?
11891.description:
Players roll the die to get various body parts. Each character is built up of a hat, a head, arms, body and feet. The various body parts has different hight, and the object is to collect 5 different parts to build the tallest character.

Ages 3 - 8
Game components: Thirty character parts, custom measuring ruler, one die

11892.name: Thunder Ball
11892.description: Thunder Ball is "The Game of Jammin' Hoops and Explosive Magic." A limited number of points are assigned various player skills - Shoot, Steal, Catch, Block and Intelligence - and then the NBA meets Harry Potter and arena combat in a fantasy basketball game to 10 points (five successful shots on the basket of your color on the hexagonal mapboard). Players are allowed two actions per turn with die rolls (augmented by player skill points) determining the success of actions ranging from shooting for a basket to using spell cards.

11893.description:
In Andantino, a game from the inventor of Trax, two players take turns placing hexagonal tiles in their own color. To start, one tile of each color are placed together on the table. Each tile placed must touch at least two pieces already in play. (Although a variant allows the second player to place one tile next to only one other tile to balance a first-player advantage.) A player wins by surrounding at least one of the opponent's tiles with tiles of his own color or by creating a line of five tiles of his own color.

Since the tiles placed are never moved, this game can alternatively be played on hexagonal paper with the players using pens of two colors.
11893.name: Andantino

11894.name: 2-Handed Whammy!
11894.description: A Rummy variant played with a deck of 220 cards where the object is to collect number sets and go out (empty your hand). Special cards include: Wild, Bonus and Whammy! Instructions include rules for individual and partnership play.

11895.name: Out of Control
11895.description: Played with a deck of 92 cards (two sets of cards numbered 1-10 in four colors, along with 12 wild cards), the object of Out of Control is to be first to complete a succession of cards from 1 to 10 in ascending order in a single color. A six-color die adds the twists to the game, with each color on the die representing a different instruction/action (such as "take a card from another player and add it to your hand").

11897.name: ITV Seven
11897.description:
For the famous Saturday afternoon sports programe 'World of Sport'
A great game of betting on the horses. Seven races and you bet on the all the one with the most money wins.
You draw 7 cards form a stanard pack and odds are worked out from the 7 cards (chart in the box shows the odds based on the cards). Player bet on one of the four siuts depending on the odds. Cards are trun over one at at time from the pack and for each suit turned over the horse one one place forward. First horse across the line wins.
Easy to play and great fun for 2 to as many as you like.

11898.name: Dixon of Dock Green
11898.description:
For the classic 1950/60's UK TV program.
Cops and Robbers board game.
Can you get the bad guy before he makes it to the airport and skips the country.

11899.description: A trivia game that has its theme based on various educational stages. The board is divided in three parts: Chemin des écoliers (pupil's path), Collège Saint-Lauréat (St. Winning college) and Université Gens-Brillants (Bright-People university). This game is full of humor and puns (the previous name list is a good example) but is strongly aimed at the Québec (Canada) French speaking population. It is, in fact, a very popular game in this region. So popular that it spawned two extensions to the game and a kid version : L'Apprenti Docte Rat.
11899.name: Le Docte Rat

11900.name: Polémique
11900.description:
Party game where controversy (polémique) is inherent, welcome and, even, provoked.

Each player is given three cards: one I agree, one I disagree and one question mark card.

In turn, each player draws an affirmation card, reads it aloud and tells everyone if (s)he is in agreement with it, paying attention to the other players' reaction. Then, each player choose, without lying, the card that describes best his opinion of the affirmation (I agree or I disagree). The question mark card is used to hide the chosen card. The player who read the card then choose three players and tries to guess their opinion. Each good guess earns him one token.

boardgameimplementation: Tic Tac Toe: jeu de réflexion
11901.description:
A very old game where each player attempts to place three of their markers (usually an X or an O) in a line on a 3x3 grid.

The Romans called this game Terni Lapilli (this does not appear to be true, Terni Lapilli seems to be a distinct and separate game). It shares the board but the players only have 3 pieces each. The same game may be played not on the grid spaces but on lines where it is aka Three Men's Morris.
boardgameversion: Haba Game in a Tin edition
Patch Products Take 'N' Play Anywhere edition
11901.name: Tic-Tac-Toe
videogamebg: Videocart-1: Tic-Tac-Toe, Shooting Gallery, Doodle, Quadra-Doodle
boardgamefamily: HABA Game in a Tin series
boardgamepodcastepisode: The Vintage Gamer Special Episode: Tic-Tac-Toe Champion

11902.name: That's Incredible!
11902.description:
The game deck consists of eighty-one cards. Each card has a letter of the alphabet, a slot machine symbol, a number between one and twenty-six and is one of four colors. The game comes with instructions to play nine games with the deck. Dice and a game pad complete the package.

Zenith – A crossword game.
Beat the Bandit – The dealer accepts bets and pays the punters for certain slot machine symbol combinations.
That’s Incredible! – A memory game that uses the colors on the cards.
Castaways – The players use the cards dealt to them to calculate a target number determined by the dealer.
Sequence 26 – A memory game that uses the letters on the cards.
Corner Bank – Players score for remembering combinations of colors.
Preposterous – Players score for remembering sequences of numbers.
Unravel – The dealer selects a secret combination of colors and the other player must deduce the combination by making guesses.
Shootout – The colors have rank and the player who reveals the highest ranked card during a round wins all cards of all the other players.

The rules give a post office box and a toll-free telephone number to encourage players to contact the publisher with game results. The game is a promotional tie-in to a popular television series of the eighties.

11904.name: Word-Wise
11904.description: Each card contains a consonant. A player can just declare any vowels needed. The players must construct words using the cards dealt to them. Handicapping rules allow players of unequal skill levels to compete.

11905.name: Carnage
boardgameexpansion: Carnage: Orb of Power & Benny the Bouncer
11905.description:
Carnage is a fantasy table-top miniatures wargame depicting a war between human barbarians and humanoid lizard people called Herptars.

The game is typical of 25mm scale fantasy wargames and involves archers, cavalry, infantry and magic-wielding sorcerers for both forces. Carnage introduces certain elements of humor to keep the game light-hearted. A good deal of this game's audience is the convention going crowd and the designers purposely implemented tongue-in-cheek silliness to keep the game in perspective.

At the heart of the carnage battlefield is a reality-altering "orb" drawn along in a cart by two flamingo-dodoes. The cart skips around the battlefield during the game causing random effects that help, hinder, annoy and amuse both sides. Effects range from rain showers to muddy the ground and slow opponents to random teleportations. Everything is all in the spirit of fun.

Overall, Carnage is a good, non-serious wargame that still requires some strategy to win.

11906.name: Tributary: A Supplement to Source of the Nile
11906.description:
Expansion for the Discovery Games edition of "Source of the Nile".

This supplement clarifies many rules from Source of the Nile, and introduces many new and optional rules including:

customizing not only the explorer but EVERY guide, bearer and askari with individual skills, stregnths, and weaknesses
rules for lady explorers
rules for developments in weapon technology, to even up the odds against the heathen savages
rules for the slave trade, and encounters with slave raiders
cape colony and the Boers
rules for shooting the rapids and going over cataracts
a name generator for tribes.




While this supplement was intended for the discovery games edition, with a little tweaking, it is serviceable for use with the Avalon Hill edition, particularly if you use the "game 2" ruleset. Using all of these rules will greatly increase the complexity of the game, but if you can handle it all, it is a very rewarding and involved simulation of an African adventure.

11907.name: High Risk!
11907.description:
HIGH RISK ! captures all the feel of international struggle - political, economic, military - and translates it into an exciting, realistic and very playable simulation that puts you at the helm of State! Assuming the role of both national leader and representative of a world ideology, you strive with other players for global domination, compete for scarce resources, make (or break!) treaties, mobilize for war or become an industrial giant! Countless opportunities - and threats - confront you and challenge your skill as a diplomat, economist and general.

HIGH RISK ! is for those who aren't afraid to play for big stakes! Whether through negotiation, bluff, treachery or just sheer force, you've got to beat the odds and the competition in order to rise to the position of WORLD LEADER!

Basic version includes a 24x36 4 color map, over 500 plastic counters, 3 types of playing cards and various other player aids.

11908.name: Clickety-Clak
11908.description: A children's game in which marbles are dropped down a chute on to the playing surface. Players score points according to where the marbles land on the board.

11909.name: Buckshot!
11909.description: One player has a puck and stick. The other players try to defend by sliding a plastic piece back and forth in front of their goals. A very fast moving, hockey-like game.

11910.name: El Dorado
11910.description: Game of logic, similar to Parker Brother's Black Box. Players try to determine the location of "treasure" by asking astute questions.

11912.description:
A game of Creating and Matching Colours.

2-4 Players ages 4-7 (front of box) or 5-8 (back of box!)

Game Contents:
o 4 playing boards
o 36 translucent tiles in 3 geometric shapes and 3 colors
o 2 special playing dice, one showing shapes and the other colors

Object of the Game:
To be the first to change the colors of the clowns to green, orange and purple.

How to Play:
o Each player, in turn, rolls the dice
o Player must then place a tile matching the shape on the die on a similar shape of a clown on the board so that the color now created on the board matches both the color rolled on the other die and the frame surrounding the clown.

Example: 1st die Triangle - 2nd Die Green

Player may either place a yellow triangular tile on a blue triangle on the board, or a blue triangular tile on a yellow triangle. Each will create the colour green.
11912.name: Color Clowns

11913.name: The Dragon and the Pearl
11913.description:
The Dragon and the Pearl is, essentially, the Britannia game concept set in China during the same era. The succession of invading hordes arrive historically accurately, but points are rewarded for surviving rather than being in the right place at the right time, so strange and interesting results are possible. A full historical background is provided so you can try to get it right if you want to, the dice-based combat system has a fair element of chance to stop it getting too serious.

Re-implements:

Britannia

boardgamehonor: 1990 Spiel des Jahres Recommended
11915.name: Tabaijana: Flucht von der Feuerinsel
11915.description:
It's a cooperative game for 2-5 players, which can be played in two forms (a simpler one and a harder one). It's goal is to rearrange crates of different colors by moving them in stacks. The ultimate goal is to reach a sorted stack before the ship has to leave the island (symbolized by 24 spaces on the map), which is the background story of the game: a volcano has erupted on an inhabited island and now all people on this island have to work together to gather as much resources, which is represented with the crates, to start a new life somewhere else.

Ages 5 and up

11916.name: Malaika
11916.description:
Malaika ... a pure abstract strategy board game for 2 players.

Played with 15 glass stones each on a hexagonal board that is divided into 96 triangles of 2 different colours.

Players may only move their stones forwards or sideways on their own 48 colour triangles.

Stones reaching the opposite side of the board are returned to and continue from the original back row start position.

It is a game of movement and capture by surrounding the opponent's stones and removing them from the board.

All possible captures must be made until a player, who has only 1 stone left, concedes defeat.

11917.name: Trivial Detective
boardgameversion: John N. Hansen Co., Inc. edition
11917.description:
From the back of the box:

Hey, listen up! If you like trivia games and you like detective games, then Trivial Detective is for you. The questions in this game are harder than the questions in most trivia games, but in this game you can travel around the board picking up clues to help you figure out the answers.

Many of the clues are also in the form of trivia questions, so the more trivia you know, the easier it will be for you to interpret the clues and win the game. You'll find clues at twelve locations around the board including the library, city hall, movie theater, sports arena, radio & TV station, art museum, museum of natural science, and the geographical & historical society.

Includes: 6 sided die, 6 pawns, game board, game cards, quiz booklet, checklist pad, and clue and answer booklet.

11918.name: Logomachy
11918.description: Logomachy plays like Casino with words: players in their turn either combine one card from the hand with cards on the table to make words, or add a card from the hand to the pool. At the end of the hand, one scores 3 points for taking the most cards, 1 for each Prize card, 2 for each Double Prize card, and 1 for each sweep (a sweep is if you remove all the cards currently on the table during your turn).

11919.description:
Thorns is a variant on the game Hex. The gameboard is made up of "Thorns", which are squares with triangles on each side. The squares and triangles are arranged in a grid.

Players alternate turns. Each turn, a player marks one of the squares with their symbol (X or O) and draws a line through the square and into two of the triangles on opposite sides. This creates a "thorn". The players are attempting to create a continuous path of thorns from one side of the board to another. Thorns are considered touching if they touch or if their triangles overlap

The first player to create a continuous path from one side of the board to the other is the winner.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.
11919.name: Thorns

11920.description:
Another of 3M's 'Paper Games', Nab consists of 15 circles arranged in a triangular pattern. The players take turns drawing lines through from 1 to 5 circles. All of the circles in the line must be in a straight line with each other and cannot have been marked through previously. The player who is forced to draw the line through the last unmarked circle loses.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.
11920.name: Nab

11921.description:
Hedron is played on a board representing an opened dodecahedron (12 sided surface) which forms 12 five-sided areas. (the "outside" of the figure is the 12th area). The players take turns placing an "X" or an "O" on one of the lines of the figure. Whoever puts marks on three or more sides of an area controls that area and gets the points for that area (printed inside). Whoever puts marks on three or more of the border sides gets the points for the "12th" area. The player with the most points wins.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.
11921.name: Hedron

11922.description:
Plasm is played on a grid of pentagons. Scattered among the pentagons are a series of two, three and five pointed shapes which are shaded.

The players take turns making either an "X" or an "O" in the pentagons. Their first move can be anywhere, but subsequent moves must be connected to a pentagon which they have already claimed.

Points are scored by surrounding the shaded areas. The player who claims the last pentagon surrounding the shaded area claims it by putting their mark inside the area. Shaded areas are scored by the number of points they have.

Play continues until all of the shaded areas have been claimed. The player with the highest point total wins.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.
11922.name: Plasm

11923.description:
Snare is played on a grid resembling a checkerboard. Half of the squares are shaded and contain a circle, the others are blank.

Players alternate turns. Each turn, a player marks an X in any unshaded square on the board. When a move is made which completely surrounds one or more of the shaded squares, the player making the move marks all of the circles as belonging to him.

Players continue to alternate moves until all shaded squares have been captured. The player capturing the most shaded squares is the winner.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.
11923.name: Snare

11924.name: Struggle
11924.description:
Struggle: A live game, full of surprises.
Five common chips are used in turns by each player, which make them move by rolling the dice, but each players seeks a different arrival pattern, imposed in the beginning by drawing a secret card. Certain areas impose specific rules. When the five chips reach the end each players scores 10 points for each well placed chip within his secret arrival pattern.

11925.name: Quizzle
11925.description: Quizzle contains four plastic crossword grids, a supply of cardboard letter tiles (also wild blanks and black squares) and a special die marked (1 1 2 2 3 *). On a player's turn, he rolls the die and places that many letters of his choice on the grid (other players simultaneously draw the same tiles but place them on their own grids as they choose). A Joker (*) counts for either 3 tiles or the replacement of an already-played tile. The game ends once the grid is filled. Only completed words count for score.

11927.name: Corrida no Hípodromo
11927.description: Corrida no Hípodromo (Hippodrome racing) - Luck in rolling the wheel and the strategy in using the race cards in favor of another horse determine how the race goes - high speed stages mixture themselves with the intermittent presence of obstacles. The winning player is the one that placed his bets on the winning horses.

11928.name: Doubletaire
11928.description:
From the box:
Doubletaire(tm) is the fast action card game for two players. Based on the classic game of Solitaire, players must race to play as many cards as possible before the game is stopped. Extra "freeze" and "undo" cards have been added to keep the game exciting and unpredictable. The game is perfect for Ages 7 and up. Winning at Doubletaire (tm) requires a combination of speed and strategy... and maybe a little luck.

11929.description:
"Go-Moku" (Japanese - also spelled "Gomoku") or "wuziqi" (Chinese) is a very old game played with a Go set. (You can also play on a sheet of graph paper using X's and O's.) It is basically an expanded tic-tac-toe, but is vastly superior to that game. The name means "five points."

It is debated whether this game originated in China or Japan, but evidence seems to lean to the former.

The object is to get five stones in a row. A Go board is 19x19, so there is a lot of room to try to get this. (Some people play on a smaller 15x15 board.) The winning move is to get four in a row open at both ends: your opponent can only block one end on his turn, and you claim the other making five in a row. Therefore, a row of three stones open at both ends needs to be blocked so it won't turn into a double-open-ended four.

So a winning move is to create a three-three or four-three or four-four: placing one stone so that it creates two winning moves at once; only one can be blocked.

This is actually the children's version of the game as played in Asia. It's been proven that Black (who goes first) can always win if played "perfectly." Long before this proof, it was realized the game was heavily weighted towards Black. So they invented Renju as an adult version of Go-Moku.
11929.name: Go-Moku

11930.name: Renju
11930.description:
Renju is the adult/tournament version of the Japanese game Go-Moku. Renju is played on a 15x15 Go board, with Go pieces.

The goal is the same: to get five stones in a row. Renju has evolved rules to balance the game however: Go-Moku heavily favors the first player.

Renju counters this with two important rules:


Setup: one player places two black stones and one white stone on the board. The other player chooses which side to play. White places one stone, then Black places two more stones. White removes one of these last two Black stones, then the game proceeds normally.
Restrictions: Black may not create a three-three or four-four. (That is, a move that creates two open-ended threes at once, or two fours at once.) Black may not create an "overline" - six or more stones in a row. White is NOT thus restricted, and can win by any of those moves, OR by forcing Black to make such a move to block White.


Renju lacks the depth of Go, but the strategies are far easier to understand, and mere mortals can become quite good at it.

Similar to:

5ive Straight
Take 5
5 in a Row
Go-Moku
Pente

11931.name: Golden Trivia Cards: National Football League (NFL) Edition
boardgameexpansion: Golden Trivia Game: National Football League (NFL) Edition
11931.description:
NFL themed trivia game from the mid-80's. Be sure you know your NFL facts to get these questions correct.


What is Miami's home stadium?
Who is the Colts' all-time rushing leader?
Name three 1983 NFL coaches who were former NFL quarterbacks.
What Super Bowl was the first played on artificial turf?
Name two of the three players who have scored six touchdowns in a game.


These are samples of some of the questions. Just remember when you play... the game was published in 1984.

11933.name: Minitar
11933.description:
While Minitar has an ostensible political theme (the 1968 US presidential election), in fact it is a completely abstract game.

Each player has a deck of cards depicting the 50 states and Washington DC, plus a wild card. On a turn a player draws a card and places it on the 8x8 board. If it is the first card played in one of the rows in the player's half of the board, it can go anywhere in that row, otherwise it must be adjacent to one of his or her already-placed cards. In addition, a card can be played on top of the opponent's card showing the same state (and the wild card can be played on top of any card).

The object is to connect the two ends of the board with a chain of cards in your color. Whoever manages this gets points equal to the number of electoral votes for the states in the chain. A match is won by the first player to reach 538 points. It is also possible to win a game by making it impossible for the other player to move.

As the rules are quite simple, most of the 28-page rulebook is taken up by background information - on the US as it was in the 1960 census, politicians holding office in the states and the federal government, the 1956, 1960, and 1964 elections, etc.

11934.name: Mighty Trees
11934.description:
An educational "collectible card game" that is built around the competition of trees for resources in order to dominate in the canopy. In the course of the game, you must deal with the natural disasters, sunlight, and combat with other trees. Painstakingly researched, the game is exceedingly detailed and amusingly illustrated.

Each deck consists of the same 100 cards, which is all you need to play--though a second deck adds a little variety. There are rules for three levels of games (seedling, timber, and elder stage) that slowly introduce all of the mechanics.

You can get more information and order at
http://mightytrees.weebly.com/
OR
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Mighty-Trees-Card-Game/199342...

11935.description:
The object of the game is to be the player with the most ice cream in their bowl when the game is over. Players have Ice Cream Sunday cups with 3 flavors of ice cream and various toppings in front of them with a group of ice cream cards in the middle. In turn, the players pull an ice cream card and click the included scoop which will show either chocolate, vanilla, or strawberry. Whichever player has the Ice Cream Sunday cup with the flavor just spun and the topping matching the ice cream card gets the ice cream card in his bowl. Keep doing this until all of the ice cream cards are taken.

Basically, this a game where you are trying to match patterns. The ice cream scoop randomizer is one of the more interesting randomizer methods in a game.
11935.name: Ice Cream Scoops of Fun

11936.name: The Battle of Balaclava
11936.description:
While the rules call this a wargame, it is highly abstract and more of a family game.

The system is an interesting attempt at representing the general flow of a given battle with very simple rules. The board consists of a (very sketchy) schematic of the battle area overlaid with arrows indicating the troop movements, much as one might see on a diagram of a battle.

The arrows are divided into spaces - on a turn, a player rolls a die and moves a piece (infantry or cavalry - the artillery does not move) along the appropriate arrow (which arrow or arrows it can use depends on where it starts). Landing on certain spaces may let you advance further, or may destroy the piece (there are a number of the latter spaces on the Light Brigade's paths). Getting to the end of an arrow destroys an enemy piece, generally, but sometimes has other effects on the opponent.

There are special rules for each group indicating what its orders are or what it actually did in the battle, more or less (some can traverse the arrows more than once, etc.).

While the box says that either 2 or 4 people can play, there is no provision in the rules for more than 2, and no obvious way to accommodate this.

Greensmith designed a similar game for Palitoy on the battle of Waterloo.

11937.name: Red Army
11937.description:
Red Army: The Destruction of Army Group Center, is a two player game on Operation Bagration, the Soviet summer offensive in Byelorussia, June 1944. Army Group Center finds itself outnumbered and eventually destroyed by four Soviet Front Armies.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 2 days
Hex: 6.2 miles / 10 kilometers
Units: Brigade to Corps

Game Inventory:
Four 17 x 22" four color mapsheets
One dual-side printed countersheet (240 1/2" counters)
One 12-page Red Army rulebook
Four Player Aid Cards
One 6-sided die

Solitaire Playability: Medium
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 6+ Hours

11938.name: The Dukes of Hazzard Card Game
11938.description:
This is basically a rummy game, with some pieces of Uno (from the makers of Uno), and the Dukes of Hazzard theme pasted on. Melds are of at least 3 good guy together, 3 bad guys together, or 3 of the same character and are obligatory if possible. You can add to your own melds and do not have to discard in going out. There are also some special cards, played as discards, to make it interesting:

Road Block -- Reverse direction and take another turn
Speed Trap -- Next player loses a turn
Parking Ticket -- Next player draws 2, cannot meld or discard
Hazzard County Clout -- Played in response to last 2 cards, reverses effects onto the original player. No effect if simply discarded.
Hogg Wild -- Next player draws four, cannot meld or discard.

None of these special cards can be picked up from the discard pile except a Hazzard County Clout that has been discarded. Scoring is the same as rummy, with a 50 point bonus for going out. First player to 500 wins.

11939.name: NASA: The Space Place Collectible Card Game
11939.description:
The object of the game is to complete more of the five missions than your opponent. Points are scored for completed missions and lost for holding multiples of various cards. Component cards are used to complete missions, effects cards affect mission completion, galaxy cards allow drawing of advantage cards which allow you to take extra turns, move cards around, look at your opponent's hand, etc. You draw and play from a common deck with six cards in hand.

The game is not collectible as all the necessary cards come in the pack. However, mine says New Millennium Deck, so there may have been other decks planned / produced.

[Update 2011] I have a "Cosmic Journeys" deck aimed at astrophysics, so there are at least two decks for this game.

[Update 2012] Additional deck "Missions to Planet Earth" also exists.

11940.name: Color Train Game
11940.description:
Discovery Toys edition:
Cubes are placed randomly on the inside track of the game board. The die is placed under the train, and the train is moved along the track. If the die matched the corresponding cube when the train is stopped, the player may take the cube and place it on their board. A black dot is another turn, and a star is wild.

Chateau edition:
Each player is trying to collect one passenger from each of four colors in his train car. One of each color passenger is waiting at each of four colored passenger stations. Each turn a player chooses a station to go to and pushes the train around the track to that station. Inside the engine is a pop-o-matic die that pops as you move the train. At the station, you may pick up a passenger that matches the color of the die if one is available and you do not already have a passenger of that color. A white spot allows you to choose any present passenger you do not already have and a black spot prevents you from taking any passenger.

11941.description: Each player starts with a different combination of star chips with pictures that match the bellies of various bears. Each turn you spin the spinner, and everyone who has a chip with that symbol may play one on their row of stars. When you complete your row of stars, you then move up the stars toward Care-a-Lot, but only one space at a time whenever someone spins that next space. The first player to Tender Heart Bear in Care-a-Lot is the winner!
11941.name: Care Bears: On the Path to Care-a-Lot

11942.description: You are trying to be the first player to go to the bake-off and make it back to the Strawberry House. Each turn you spin the spinner and move to the next space of the color indicated. But watch out for the Peculiar Purple Pieman from Porcupine Peak! If you land on one of his spaces, you will have to pick a pie or two and hope it is not his -- or you have to go back to a purple space.
11942.name: Strawberry Shortcake in Big Apple City

11943.description: Each player has a selection of animals they are trying to get into the Ark. On each turn, spin the spinner. There are spaces with two different animals that allow you to place one of those animals in the ark if you have one. If you spin the blank space, you put nothing in the ark. The first player to get all of their animals in the ark wins!
11943.name: Noah's Ark

11944.name: MacDonald's Farm Game
11944.description:
Four Scotch brothers, Sandy, Neil, jack and Rob MacDonald, own four adjourning farms. But they have no livestock, no poultry, not even a dog for their farms. They can get what they need at the County fair, but because the supp of each item is limited as e each brother wants to be the FIRST to stock his farm, the competition is keen and exciting. In playing MacDonald's Farm Game, you can take the part of one of the Scotch brothers and attempt by "Selecting Stock at the County Fair" -- "Cornering the Market" -- "Trading" and "Unloading Surpluses" to be the FIRST to stock up your own farm.

Each player tries to fill his farm with the exact animals needed. On each turn, you spin the spinner and must take one group of animals, if possible, from the section the spinner lands on. If you have too many of a specific animal, you may attempt to trade by spinning. If the spinner lands on a trade space, you may attempt to negotiate a single trade with any of your opponents. Otherwise, your turn ends. Once you have all of your needed animals, you get rid of your excess at the county fair. Again, you spin and if you land on a county fair space, you may return one group listed there to the stock. Otherwise your turn ends. However, if you forget to declare that you are going to the fair, you must draw animals as though it were a normal turn.

boardgamehonor: 2008 Spiel des Jahres Recommended
2010 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Nominee
2010 Lys Grand Public Finalist
11945.description:
US-edition

Creator (original version): Erik Nielsen
Publisher: Endless Games

From Publisher Website: 4 Cards... 1 Pair... 100 reasons why you SHOULD be right. It's not a word game. It's not a strategy game. It's not a bluffing game, yet all three of these elements are combined in this uniquely simple, excitingly fun, and extremely addictive game: Linq. The object of the game is to guess which two players are the Linq. If you are the Linq, you must think like your partner, and connect with them. The only problem is... You don't know who your partner is!

German edition

artwork: Sebastian Wagner
editor: Andrea Meyer
publisher: BeWitched-Spiele
game length: ca. 45 minutes

Linq combines bluff elements with associative gaming. 4-8 players ages 10 and up try to find their ever changing partners by associating freely to their LINQ-words. An intuitive scoring mechanism shows who was best able to linq with the others in the end.

The game contains 58 card pairs with nearly 700 words, 4 question marks, wooden pieces for counting points, a 12-sided die, and the rulebook.

French edition

artwork: Pierre Lechevalier (aka Piero)
publisher: In Ludo Veritas

Two spies have to meet each other. All they have in common is a password.

All the others players are counterspies triyng to identify and confuse them.

The game contains 2 * 50 spy cards with 10 words each (500 different passwords ),
10 counterspy cards, counters, rulebook
11945.name: Linq

11946.name: Riot Act
11946.description: From Publisher Website: This "Act-Up, Act-Out, Action game is a REVOLUTIONARY new way to play Charades! Players must act out what is described on the "Act" card, in whatever manner the "Riot" deck tells them. The "Riot" cards range from a simple adverb, to combining your action with some bizarre task not seen everyday. For example, you might be asked to "Milk a cow..." FORGETFULLY. Or, you may have to "Change a baby's diaper..." WHILE BEING CHASED BY KILLER BEES. To win at Riot Act, be the first team to reach the center of the board... LOVINGLY... WALKING ON HOT COALS!

11947.name: Combat Zone
11947.description: Combat Zone is a tabletop miniatures skirmish game in 25mm scale. CZ is set in an alternate near future where corporations have walled off cities to protect their economic interests. Economies have crumbled as corporations have turned to military warfare as a means of assuring their financial futures. Destitute gangs, corporate para-military and combat robots all take part in battles to scratch out an existence in this Mad Max-esque world.

11948.name: Généric
11948.description: In this French party game about the cinema, each team tries to make a movie by collecting cards (actor, actress, director, scenario, set and advertisement). This is done by different means : finding movie titles containing a particular word, guessing the music hummed by your teammate, guessing an actor's name from the description given by your teammate, etc...

boardgamehonor: 2006 Charles S. Roberts Best World War II Boardgame Nominee
2007 Golden Geek Best Wargame Nominee
11949.description:
(from MMP website:)

Shifting Sands is a point-to-point movement, card driven game based on the World War II African campaigns of 1940-1943. From the first Italian attempts to cross "The Wire" through the Torch invasion, all aspects of the campaign for North Africa are covered including the Abyssinian Campaign of 1940-1941. Like the commanders of the day, you'll need to try and achieve your goals while events in other theaters influence your ability to maintain any semblance of a plan.

Contents:

One mapsheet (approx 22"x32")
One 36-page booket with rules, designer notes, and scenarios; only 16 pages of actual game rules
Two countersheets - one 5/8" and one 5/8" and 1/2" mixed
2 decks of 55 cards - one allied and one axis
2 player aid cards
dice
11949.name: Shifting Sands
boardgamepodcastepisode: Point 2 Point Episode 11 - CSR, Shifting Sands, and Mike Rinella

11950.description: The classic Monopoly game with a Marvel Universe theme. Buy and sell individual comics which replace the classic Boardwalk and Park Place. Thwipp and Snikt cards replace Community Chest and Chance.
11950.name: Monopoly: Marvel Comics

11951.name: Le Tour du Lys
11951.description:
Trivia game from the same people who brought us the famous and much loved Le Docte Rat. This time, they chose the Québec province (Canada) tourist attractions as a theme.

The object of the game is to be the first to reach Québec, the province's capital. You move around the lily (tour du lys), the province's emblem, trying to reach each of the four predetermined mandatory regions. Once you do, you try to answer correctly one question. After you successfully answered one question for each of these four regions, you have the right to begin your trip towards Québec which is ruled by a different mechanic.

11952.name: Hoop Hysteria
11952.description:
This is Sportsfan's Hoop Hysteria - The College Basketball Trivia game.

This is an interesting sports trivia game for fans of college basketball. Each round one player is the offensive team (home team starts) and rolls d6 that has four results (1/6) Turnover - lose possession. (4/6) Shot - Offense selects whether they are attempting 2pt or 3pt shot. Defense reads the question and if the offense gets it right (separate questions for 2 and 3pt shots) they get the points. Regardless of whether they answer correctly, play goes to the defense. (1/6) Shot/Foul - Offense selects 2 or 3pt shot, but if they get it right, they get a shot at the 1pt bonus question too.

From the back of the box :

Over 2,000 questions on NCAA Division I men's basketball trivia. Contains questions on every major college basketball program. Includes a scoreboard, a 60-second time, and a custom die. Scores like a real game.

11953.name: Pop-Up Store Game
11953.description:
From the rules:

"This wonderful Toy and Candy Store game with its "Pop-Up" counters is made especially for children to play going shopping. They have fun as they go from counter to counter, buying articles on their shopping list with play money, and stopping to eat at the soda fountain - just as in a real store.

The object of the game is to complete your shopping list, have the packages wrapped paid for, and be the first to leave the store."

Not much of a game here, but an incredibly cool "pop-up" board. Allegedly from the 1950s

11954.name: Paladin
11954.description:
Theme
Brave knights are gathering to plan their honourable endeavours and to find out who will be the bravest Paladin facing the most honourable missiona.

Goal
To collect as many honour points as possible by winning mission cards.

Setup
Each player gets 5 player tokens of one colour.

The 18 mission cards are sorted into two stacks, according to their honour point values (1-6). Each stack is shuffled separately, then the stack with the lower value mission cards (queen's deck, values 1-3) is placed on top of the other (king's deck, values 4-6).

Mission cards equal to the number of players are laid out, face up.

The card dealer shuffles the 42 paladin cards and hands out 4-6 (depending on the number of players) cards to each player. Paladin cards have values from 0-9.

Game play
Each player, beginning with the start player, puts one of his/her paladin cards next to one of the mission cards, face down, and marks it with one of his/her player tokens. This paladin is called the leading paladin. When each mission card has a leading paladin, players continue playing cards clockwise until each player has placed a card beside each mission.
Before placing a card, players may look at one of the cards another player has already placed. Each player can only play one paladin per mission.
When each player has only one card left, the paladin cards are resolved, starting with the first mission and the first card that was placed there. Each player has the following options:

Beat the leading paladin if your card has a higher value (or in case they are equal, if it is a red number).
Take the face-down paladin card back on your hand.
Discard the face-down paladin card.




This continues until all cards at the first mission have been dealt with. The player whose card is the last to stay wins the mission and places it, together with the winning paladin card, in front of him/herself. The same is done for the other mission cards.

The player with the fewest honour points is the dealer of the next round and hands out paladin cards until everyone has the same number of cards as in the first round. The dealer then lays out new mission cards and determines a start player.

The game ends when there are not enough mission cards left for another round. Each player counts the honour points from the missions he/she won and adds bonus points for all paladin cards with red numbers that the/she has in front of him/herself. The player with the most points wins the game.

11955.name: Waz Baraz
11955.description: During the thousandth Moon night the Dancing witches gather for an ancient magical ritual. Move around the Magic Circle and discover the Dancing Leaders in a deductive game with an enchanted setting.

11956.name: The Monster Squad Game
11956.description: Based on the old "popular" television series, this game is a simple children's game about getting your monster squad back to their proper lair or home.

11957.name: InterSpace
11957.description: InterSpace is a print-and-play space exploration & exploitation boardgame for 2 to 4 players. Each player assumes the role of a civilization that has grown beyond its home world and is expanding into the Universe. Players build ships, explore space, colonize planets, and trade with or wage war on the other players. Players also develop new technologies and expand their industrial bases, allowing them to build more and better ships.

11958.name: Cup Final
11958.description:
This game is very similar to the Palitoy "Striker" soccer game, but without the build quality or fun factor.

The pitch is made of a peculiar green material with a strange foam backing that sticks to the carpet; the goals are identical to the one in Striker, but with plastic netting. The game comes supplied with two teams - red and blue, but instead of 5 players per team of Striker, Cup Final only has 3 players on each side.

The two outfield players are plastic with a metal kicking leg, with one player having a bent leg, and one a straight leg. The straight legged player had a scooped foot for lobbing the ball, but this mechanism doesn't work very well. The kicking action is controlled by a button on the back of the base as opposed to the "bash 'em on the head" mechanism used in Striker. Additionally, the figures are very badly designed, and the slightest movement causes them to fall over (are they Christian Ronaldo in disguise?).

The goalkeepers are identical in design to the original Striker goalkeepers, as they swivel at the waist and have a crooked arm for throwing the ball out.

The ball is not round, but more of a honeycomb. One half of the ball is coloured red, the other half blue. The team whose colour is on the top face of the ball when it comes to rest has the right to play the ball, so the purpose of the game is always keep the top face of your colour visible while dribbling.

Basically it's a cheap reproduction of Striker by Palitoy. Avoid.

11959.name: Subway Toronto
11959.description:
A race through the underground tunnels of Toronto's subway system! On the board is a map showing each of the city stations - some are junctions between the different directional lines, and some are terminals at the ends.

Everyone starts at Union Station, with at least 6 destination cards. Hand in destinations that you pass by or land on. If others land on your destination, you may hand in your card OR force them to add another destination from the draw pile!

You move by rolling a special 6-sided die; instead of a 6, it contains the word 'SUBWAY' -- rolling that allows you to jump to one of YOUR stations. Otherwise, move the number rolled without changing your direction, as that can only change when on a junction station.

As well, many of the stations have a signal on them to follow: amber (pick up another destination), green (usually good, useful cards), or red (frequently bad - adding destination, or flinging you to an end of the board). Adds some chaos to the game, but in a fun way!

11960.name: FBI Crime Resistance Game
11960.description: Milton Bradley FBI Crime Resistance board game. For 2-4 players and for Ages 8 - 14. Travel the pathways on the board to collect "Crime Resistance" cards. Use the rotating discs to enter and leave each corner area. After collecting at least 4 resistance cards, try to match one with a "Victim" card to win.

boardgamehonor: 2001 Charles S. Roberts Best DTP-Produced Boardgame Nominee
11961.description:
Covering the battle north of Madrid, this game will covers one of the most significant battles of the Spanish Civil War.
Units will be at battalion/regiment level and hexes will be .75 kilometers wide. The Battles of the Spanish
11961.name: Guadalajara 1937

11962.description:
From the box: "The rabbits are hopping around in the garden. Each one tries to get to the card with the yellow border and the stalk on it first. If this is the case the corresponding player can take a carrot from the stock in the center as a reward. At once a new starting square has to be fixed: the "old" target card is simply turned over. The picture on the backside shows the new target square. Who can find the card which has the same picture? It marks the new square they must all aim for and the stalk is placed on it. Again the rabbits are zipping through the garden. Who will be lucky enough and clever enough to collect the largest amount of carrots? A surprising competition game with dice."

This is not just a roll and move game; choices must be made by the players on each turn.

Contents: 4 wooden rabbits, 1 wooden carrot stalk, 16 cards to mark the path, 15 little wooden carrots, 2 wooden dice (marked with 1 - 3 dots each)
11962.name: Rübenratz

11964.description:
Bloody Ridge is a small, low counter density addition to the award winning Tactical Combat Series (TCS) by The Gamers and designed by noted Guadalcanal historian Michael S. Smith.

Bloody Ridge portrays the fighting that occurred around “Bloody Ridge” on the island of Guadalcanal from 12-14 September 1942 between US and Imperial Japanese forces. The Japanese are attempting to recapture Henderson Field, the airstrip they abandoned when the Marines first landed on 7 August. The Marines are trying to hold the perimeter south of Henderson Field to prevent the Japanese from recapturing the airstrip.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 20 minutes
Hex: 125 yards / 114 meters
Units: Infantry sections & platoons

Game Inventory:
One 17 x 22" full color maps
One dual-side printed countersheet (280 1/2" counters)
One 28-page TCS v3.1 specific rulebook
One 16-page Bloody Ridge specific rulebook
One 4-page TCS v3.1 Charts & Tables booklet
Two 6-sided dice

Solitaire Playability: Medium
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 1 or more
Playing Time: 4 hours or more
11964.name: Bloody Ridge

11965.name: Topminos
11965.description:
Game consists mainly of a 3x3 gameboard and lots of different transparent perspex tiles with 1-5 dots (also printed somewhere in a 3x3 grid) on them.

Players try to form stacks of tiles and score the visible points. Main rule is that you aren't allowed to place a dot on top of another dot. On each turn the player has the choice of starting a new stack using one or more of his tiles or to upgrade an existing stack. If you manage to complete a 9-dot-stack you can continue placing tiles.

Play until all tiles are used or nobody can play. Highest score wins - that's it!

Identical in materials but different in rules is Hi-Spot/Stack-Ominos.

11966.name: Battle at Sea
11966.description:
Abstract naval combat and merchant game. Seven battleships and 3 merchant ships for each side. Equal combat capabilities for all ships, merchant ships take less damage. Probability of a hit depends on distance. Movement reduced for damaged ships. Movement is variable depending on wind direction and speed. Players decide whether to change wind on each turn, die rolls determine if a change will be allowed then the new direction and speed. Long game: first player to get a merchant ship to away port and back home wins. Short game, points are awarded depending on the order that merchant ships get to away port. Very simple rules with examples. Away port is across the board diagonally from the home port meaning the players' paths cross, making battle likely.

From the box: '"Seeschlacht" does not just mean Battle at Sea. Treacherous seas, unpredictable winds and valuable cargo to protect make this game a challenge to even the most experienced seafarers.'

For 2 players, Ages 10 and up.

boardgamehonor: 1987 Charles S. Roberts Best Pre-World War II Board Game Nominee
2004 Charles S. Roberts Best Pre-World War II Boardgame Nominee
2004 Charles S. Roberts Best Wargame Graphics Nominee
11967.description:
The Battles of Abensberg, Eckmühl, and Ratisbon.

Seven Days of 1809 uses the game system that first appeared in "Six Days of Glory," which covers the Battles near Montmirail in February of 1814.

GAME SYSTEM: DAYS System
- scale = 1,600m/hex,
- time = 6 hours/GT,
- strength = 800-1,000 men/SP, .
11967.name: The Seven Days of 1809
boardgamefamily: Campaigns of Napoleon System: Days Series

11968.name: Harry Potter Gnome Toss Card Game
11968.description:
Gnomes, gnomes, gnomes, who goes next? Only the gnomes know!

Follow the gnomes and slap down your cards as fast as you can or you might get stuck with more gnomes than you know what to do with.

Keep you eyes on the gnomes - they bite! Watch out for the other players too - they're just waiting to bury you under a fresh pile of gnomes!

The first player to de-gnome their hand wins the game!

11969.name: Set Sail!
11969.description:
Set Sail! is a fun, fast-paced card game for the whole family that draws players into the Age of Sail. Be the first to exploit the resources of the new world!

Play is fast as all players simultaneously build ships and set sail! Ships are built by playing cards from your deck in order onto ships shared by all players. Play the last card on a ship to set sail. The first player to use all his or her cards wins!

Featuring original illustrations inspired by the artwork and national flags of the period, Set Sail! educates as well as entertains. It only takes a few minutes to learn and features a number of rule variations to intrigue players of all ages.

11970.name: Dracula's Revenge
11970.description:
Dracula’s Revenge is a horror-themed, tabletop game of tactical combat. One side plays Dracula and his coven of vampires and other minions who are set to take revenge on London. The other side plays Professor Van Helsing and his faithful friends who rise to put an end to the vampire lord’s threat once again.
Dracula’s Revenge is the first in the "Gothica" series of games. Each entry in the series shares the same basic rules system. This allows you to put the components from the various games together to play whole new games that are larger and stranger than the originals.

Description from the Box
Eleven years after faking his death, Count Dracula returns to London with one thing on his mind: REVENGE! All that stands between him and his goal are Professor Van Helsing and his loyal band of friends. Choose sides and claim your stake. This one's going to be bloody!

Dracula's Revenge is the board game of the desperate war between hunters and vampires in Victorian England. Returning to London eleven years after his apparent death, Count Dracula thirsts for revenge, and he's created an army of undead to help him get it. Prepared this time for the vampire threat, Van Helsing and his stalward friends stand ready to put Dracula back into his grave for the ultimate time!

Gameplay is fast and deadly. Players move characters around a board depicting the catacombs snaking beneath London's teeming streets, battling against each other for their lives. On his side, Dracula has vampires of all stripes - she-wolves, nosferatu, and seductive vampiress - as well as the mindless minions they've enslaved. Against them, Van Helsing leads a force of heroes armed with stakes, crossbows, and a fearsome faith in God.

In the battle between good and evil, it's time to choose sides.

The game comes with:

20 tiles (used to form the board, making for nearly unlimited replay value)
36 characters (including rules for building forces of your own)
36 action cards
9 dice
12 doors
48 plastic counter stands
12 vampire mist counters
2 dice screens
2 quick-reference cards
32-page rulebook

boardgamehonor: 2004 Fairplay À la carte Winner
2004 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Nominee
2004 Spiel des Jahres Recommended
2005 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Foreign Game for Beginners
2006 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Nominee
2007 Hra roku Nominee
11971.description:
Cockroach Poker is a reverse set collection game that has nothing to do with poker – except that the game is all about bluffing, but with cards that show cockroaches, rats and stink bugs instead of queens, 10s and aces. The goal of the game is to force another player to collect 4 of any one type of critter.

The deck includes 64 cards, with eight copies of eight types of critters. To set up the game, shuffle the deck and deal the cards out to players.

On a turn, a player takes one card from his hand, lays it face down on the table, slides it to a player of his choice, and declares a type of critter, e.g., "Stink bug". The player receiving the card either

• Accepts the card, says either "true" or "false", then reveals the card. If this player is wrong in her claim, she keeps the card on the table in front of her face up; if she is right, the player who gave her the card places it face up before him.

• Peeks at the card, then passes it face down to another player, either saying the original type of critter or saying a new type. This new player again has the choice of accepting the card or passing it, unless the card has already been seen by all other players in which case the player must take the first option.

The game ends when a player has no cards to pass on his turn or when a player has four cards of the same critter on the table in front of him. In either case, this player loses and everyone else wins.
11971.name: Cockroach Poker
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGTG 133 - 100 Great Games, part 2 (with Stephen Glenn and Mark Jackson)
Cult of the New Board Game Podcast Episode 017 – Our Podcast Subscriptions
Episode 18 - Small Games, COIN Games, And Star Wars Rebellion Review
Episode 28:  HeavyCon 2016 Recap - Jon Gilmour Interview
Episode 9: Panamax, They Live, and Solforge
Kakerlakenpoker
MN 0095 Lying, Cheating, Bluffing
MN 0128 Short Social Games with Tim Fowers
